1 n Plautus hiatus occurs between two words closely connected —a preposition and its noun, a pair of nouns, a noun and its verb, an adjective and its noun, ἂι, de ea, octo hominum, gratiam habeo, tuam amicam, eri imperia.

But hiatus is practically confined to cases when there is a pause in metre or in sense which at least tones down the harshness. 'l'hus there may be hiatus at the caesura. Most frequently where hiatus occurs there is a pause in both sense and mette, and, even where these double pauses coincide, in an overwhelming number os cases there is no hiatus, eg. when one speaker leaves a line unfinished and another takes it up hiatus is rare.

Hiatus most frequently accompanies breaks in sense when they are considerable, especially is there is a change os speakers.

Most frequently hiatus is met with in the case of mono· syllables with a long vowel (pro, de, Sec.) or a short vowel is the word ends with m (nam, cum) in cases like quae ego, qui in, nam ego, ne ego, qui homo, di ament, cum Alcumena, quam ob rem, qui obviam.

Cases of hiatus are pretty frequent before homo, in nom.
